div.head:
Embleme 38. Of the Secrets of Nature.
Rebis is, as Hermaphroditus, produced from the two moun
tains of Mercury and Venus.

lg.l: Rebis is by the Ancients calld a TwinneTwin,
Containing male and female sex therein:
For Hermes and Venus their Hermaphrodite
Is in two mountains sayd to have birthright.
A double sex despite not, for a King
Will from the selfe same man and woman spring.

div.head: Discourse 38.
div.ab:
Socrates being demanded what Country man hee was, answered a-
Citizen of the world: by which his intention was signify, that though
hee was borne at Athens as to person, yet in mind hee freely beheld-
the whole world, as his Country, and the things therein contained,-
the whole earth being a wise mans Country, where hee lives well:-
Soe if any one aske the Philosophers what Countryman their-
Hermaphrodite is, they answer, hee belongs to the world, or is in all-
corners of the world, where the Elements can be found, as the Sonne
of the wise, who hath a country coḿon with them: But seing that
it happens not that any man is borne twice or oftener, nor first enters
this light in severall but in one place, as Socrates is owned to be an-
Athenian, soe is Rebis reputed an inhabiter of two mountains, that is,
Mercury and Venus, from whence allso the name of Hermaphrodite-
given him by both parents; a noble and large country is indeed noe-
small helpehelp to doe things excellently well, in which Citizens are præ
ferrd before forreignersforeigners, and promoted to publicke offices, that they
may not lye in obscurity (as it happens in a meane place, and soe
something of light come to them from the country) but Shew them
selves rather with their owne virtues, even in the small affaires of
a house, and give light themselves to their owne country: After this
manner these mountains unknowne to many men doe acquire fame
from the Herinaphrodite by reason of his illustrious actions, and name
famous throughout the whole world. For who though never soe-
little versed in the Philosophers bookes hath not knowne Rebis?-
Who hath not seen or beheld AndrogynusAndrogynous with two heads? Hee verily
has been knowne to the IndyesIndies themselves, and his fame hath been-
dispersed farther, than the fame even of King Alexander: Many-
men doe travell out of farre countryes to see and discourse some
learned man, or otherwise remarkeableremarkable for singular military in
dustry, art or science, but many more will betake themselves to-
the sayd Mountains of Rebis, provided they can learne where-
they may be found: With how great study and care did Morienus-
being departed from Rome seeke and at length find Adferus Alexan
drinus, hee himselfe declares in his booke, and therefore was to be-
esteemed more happy, and acceptable to God, in that hee had from a-
living teacher, and not from dumbedumb masters learnt, and beheld this
thing, that is, the native place of Rebis; noe lesse assiduity and-
diligence ought they to use, who seeke the country of Rebis by-
themselves, being informed by reason, and the documents of books:
But though some books may sometimes seem to be clear and conspi

cuous, yet they are soe veildveiled and clouded with intricacy and ob
scurity, that by reason thereof it is very difficult to make distinction:
Wherefore wee must cautiously proceed with them, that they, which are
præpard for remedy, may not be usd for poyson: They are certainly-
a vast ocean, in which expert mariners saylingsailing may by Astronomi
callAstronomical instruments know the latitude, or elevation of the ÆquatorEquator above
the Horizon, the Magnet Shewing the North pole, but by noe means
the longitude, or how great an internall of degrees they are distant-
from the first Meridian, which is next to the fortunate Islands; soe-
that they are uncertaine in what place they may be between west-
and east: What therefore is here to be done? That which the same-
Mariners use to doe, consult experience with reason, and thereby-
learne how to determine a long voyage by particular signs, promon
toryespromontories, Islands, and other things, that they may not for want of consi
deration fall upon Sands and rocks: But here is lesse danger, if the
thing prosper not, but if soe, greater gaine, than there, where goods-
and life are lost in an houre: But the mountaine of the Philoso
phicall Mercury is not Nonacris, nor Atlas, where sometimes it is reported
to be brought forth, but Parnassus with two tops, in one of which-
Hermes, in the other Venus resides: Hee allso is Apollo with the Mu
ses, and Hippocrene, the fountaine of Pegasus, with laurelllaurel allwayes
green: it is one mountaine by name, but really two, as Hermaphro
ditus is beheld with two heads, and two members in one body: But-
what man of a thousand persists in ascending to the top of this-
mountaine? Who dos not begin to hæsitatehesitate at the bottome being-
impeded by I know not what obstacles? Whoever attaines to the-
midle of it? for
Non levis ascensus, si quis petat ardua, sudor
Plurimus hunc tollit, nocturnæ insomnis olive
Immoritur, delet, quod mox laudaverat in se,
Qui cupit æternæ donari frondis honore.
Wherefore it is noe strange thing, if onely one of tenne thousand un
dertake these Herculean labours, soe as to sett foot on the top of the
mountaine, and enjoy the immortallimmortal reward of a laurelllaurel garland,
which that all those that are upright, docible, and addicted to vir
